replies.body:
Watch a few higher-elo junglers play, then do it yourself.

Jungling is the hardest role, since you need total map awareness and good judgement on where to go, and you need to plan ahead so you end up in the right places while you farm. It just takes practice.

I forget what episode of Family Guy it was, or what game they were talking about, but there was a pretty applicable quote from the episode you can apply to League: "You don't win, you just do a little better every time"

I feel muscle memory is a great part of performing great mechanically, and being able to guess where people might be in 30 seconds is great for awareness. But like everything else in life, it's a skill gained slowly.

Something that a high level jungler would be able to do consistently is predict what buff a jungler will start at, and which lane they will gank after both buffs, or maybe if they will power farm and B for level 4. Being able to predict both of these means you can shut down a jungler hard by removing his double buffs with a well timed countergank/invade, but is not necessarily the best way to "git gud" as others say.
if you care so little about the game, why do you care about learning it? just play for fun. rank and skill don't matter if you don't care.
If you're going to make that many assumptions coming right out of the gate, I think you're already beyond help.

If you have a life you don't need to care too much about the game then, stick to bots or something.

Besides, if you really want to learn and improve you'd seek out resources like League of Legends Wiki or YouTube guides.

Those two will do better in every way in terms of teaching you how to play than walls of text.

Practice Tool for pathings, clears, ganks against bots. Do a 1v3 or 5 and carry it against high damage or cc targets. 

Tool is also nice for calculating damage on dummies through build as well as practicing champions in general against multiple dummies through animation cancels, flash plays, juggling, etc. --  or just to cs better.
